content.description:
In 1960, an invasive fly was introduced to the Galapagos islands.

To understand the relationship between the invasive fly and the tree finches that live on the island, researchers examined the mating success of two species of finches. Some finches had nests with flies and some did not. The data from the study are in the table.

PERCENTAGE OF SUCCESSFUL MATINGS OF GAL√ÅPAGOS FINCHES

Invasive fly Present inthe Nest
 Invasive fly Not Presentin the Nest

Small finch
 <math alttext="43%" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mn>43</mn> <mo>%</mo> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>
 <math alttext="93%" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>93</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

Medium finch
 <math alttext="35%" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>35</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="80%" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>80</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>
content.question: Based on the table, which of the following claims about the relationship between the tree finch and the invasive fly is best supported?

choices.label: The flies and finches have a commensal relationship; finches provide a home for the fly, but finches are not affected by the presence of the fly.
The flies and finches have a mutualistic relationship; the finch provides a home for the fly, and the fly helps the breeding success of the finch.
The flies and finches have a parasitic relationship; the finches provide a home for the fly, and the fly decreases the breeding success of the finches.
The flies and finches have a competitive relationship; the two species feed on the same food, and the finches are more successful at feeding than the flies are.

content.answer: The flies and finches have a parasitic relationship; the finches provide a home for the fly, and the fly decreases the breeding success of the finches.

skill.text: Skill 5.C: Explain patterns and trends in data to draw conclusions.
